abstract.shortdesc: The Ops Console provides cloud admins a web GUI to monitor and view data about their cloud infrastructure.

section.p: You can use the Operations Console (Ops Console) for to view data about your Helion cloud infrastructure in a web-based graphical user interface (GUI) to make sure your cloud is operating correctly. By logging on to the console, administrators can manage data in the following ways:

ul.li: Triage alarm notifications in the central dashboard
Monitor the environment by giving priority to alarms that take precedence
Manage compute nodes and easily use a form to create a new host
Refine the monitoring environment by creating new alarms to specify a combination of metrics, services, and hosts that match the triggers unique to an environment
Plan for future storage by tracking capacity over time to predict with some degree of reliability the amount of additional storage needed.

section.p: The Business Logic Layer of Ops Console is a middleware component that serves as a single point of contact for the user interface to communicate with OpenStack services such as Monasca, Nova, and others.

section.title: Connecting to the Operations Console
section.p: To connect to OpsConsole you will need to understand the following tasks:

li.xref: Ensure your login has the required access credentials
Optionally use a Hostname OR virtual IP address to access Ops Console

section.p: OpsConsole will always be accessed over port 9095.

section.title: Required Access Credentials
section.p: In previous versions of OpsConsole you were required to have only the password for the Administrator account (admin by default). Now the Administrator user account must also have all of the following credentials:

row.entry: Admin role on at least one project
Admin or Monasca-user role on admin project

section.note: If your login account has administrator role on the administrator project, then you only need to make sure you have the administrator role on the default domain.
section.p: During installation, an Administrator account called “admin” is created default.
During installation, an Administrator password is randomly created by default. It is not recommend that you change the default password.

ol.li: To display the password, log on to the lifecycle manager and run: cat ~/service.osrc

section.title: Connect Through a Browser
section.p: The following instructions will show you how to find the URL to access Ops Console. You will use SSH, also known as Secure Socket Shell, which provides administrators with a secure way to access a remote computer.

ol.li: To log on to the lifecycle manager (deployer node), run: $ ssh <lifecycle manager>

To find the URL, run: $ . ~/service.osrc && openstack endpoint list | grep opsconsole | grep public Sample output: | eec0d2c02d9341db8e535b8dea561d6a | region1 | opsconsole | opsconsole | True | public | https://myhelion.test:9095/api/v1/
To access Ops Console, in the sample output, remove everything after port 9095 and in a browser, type: https://myhelion.test:9095

section.title: Optionally use a Hostname OR virtual IP address to access Ops Console
section.note: If you can access Ops Console using the above instructions, then you can skip this section. These steps provide an alernate way to access Ops Console if the above steps do not work for you.
section.p: To find your hostname OR IP address:

ol.li: Navigate to and open in a text editor the following file: network_groups.yml
If your administrator set a hostname value in the external-name field, you will use that hostname when logging in to OpsConsole. or example, in a browser you would type: https://VIP:9095

If your administrator did not set a hostname value, then to determine the IP address to use, from your lifecycle manager, run: Grep vip -HZN-WEB /etc/hosts The output of that command will show you the virtual IP address you should use. For example, in a browser you would type: https://VIP:9095

section.title: Getting Help
section.p: On each of the Operations Console pages there is a help menu that you can click on to take you to a help page specific to the console you are currently viewing.

Click on the Get Help For This Page link which will open the help page in a new tab in your browser.
